</figure><p id="4bfd" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">Angular. The framework that has seen more seasons than your favorite TV show. While the tech world is notorious for its rapid changes and fleeting trends, Angular has managed to stick around like that catchy tune you can’t get out of your head. But why? Let’s dive deep into the reasons developers are still enamored with this enduring framework.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>

<p id="d129" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">Before we delve into the ‘why’, let’s take a quick stroll down memory lane.</p>

<figcaption class="pa fe pb na nb pc pd be b bf z dt">Timeline of Angular Versions</figcaption></figure><p id="b334" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">Angular, initially released in 2010 by Google, was groundbreaking. It brought two-way data binding, dependency injection, and a modular architecture to the table. Fast forward to today, and we’ve seen multiple versions, each refining and enhancing the framework.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>
<div class="gm gn go gp gq"><div class="ab ca"><div class="ch bg fy fz ga gb"><p id="ae72" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj"><strong class="nq gu">2. Mature and Reliable</strong></p>
<p id="3159" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">Angular isn’t the new kid on the block anymore. It’s matured like a fine wine (or cheese, if you’re into that). With maturity comes reliability. Developers know what to expect, and there’s a certain comfort in that familiarity.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>
<div class="gm gn go gp gq"><div class="ab ca"><div class="ch bg fy fz ga gb"><p id="44df" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj"><strong class="nq gu">3. Strong Community and Ecosystem</strong></p>
<p id="1e63" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">A strong community is the backbone of any successful framework. Angular’s community is vibrant, active, and ever-growing. From forums to GitHub repositories, there’s always someone ready to lend a hand or share a plugin.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>

Why reinvent the wheel when Angular provides a fully-equipped toolbox?</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>
<div class="gm gn go gp gq"><div class="ab ca"><div class="ch bg fy fz ga gb"><p id="8fda" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj"><strong class="nq gu">6. Flexibility and Scalability</strong></p>
<p id="7e12" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">Whether you’re building a simple website or a complex enterprise application, Angular scales beautifully. Its modular architecture ensures that your app remains maintainable as it grows.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p id="03cf" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">Yes, Angular has a learning curve. But like climbing a mountain, the view from the top is worth the effort. Once mastered, developers can harness the full power of the framework, making development faster and more efficient.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>
<div class="gm gn go gp gq"><div class="ab ca"><div class="ch bg fy fz ga gb"><p id="bcc6" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj"><strong class="nq gu">9. Integration Capabilities</strong></p>
<p id="ffcb" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">Angular plays well with others. Whether you’re integrating with third-party libraries or other frameworks, Angular’s flexibility shines through.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>

<p id="09cb" class="pw-post-body-paragraph no np gt nq b nr ns nt nu nv nw nx ny nz oa ob oc od oe of og oh oi oj ok ol gm bj">In the ever-evolving world of tech, Angular has shown its ability to adapt and evolve. With regular updates and a forward-thinking approach, it’s a framework that’s here to stay.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="ab ca om on oo op" role="separator"><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os ot"></span><span class="oq bx bl or os"></span></div>

Why Are Developers Still Using Angular?













Hassan Trabelsi



·Follow




Published inStackademic



·

3 min read·
Aug 10, 2023








--



22







Listen









Share












Angular. The framework that has seen more seasons than your favorite TV show. While the tech world is notorious for its rapid changes and fleeting trends, Angular has managed to stick around like that catchy tune you can’t get out of your head. But why? Let’s dive deep into the reasons developers are still enamored with this enduring framework.




1. A Brief History of Angular
Before we delve into the ‘why’, let’s take a quick stroll down memory lane.


Timeline of Angular VersionsAngular, initially released in 2010 by Google, was groundbreaking. It brought two-way data binding, dependency injection, and a modular architecture to the table. Fast forward to today, and we’ve seen multiple versions, each refining and enhancing the framework.




2. Mature and Reliable
Angular isn’t the new kid on the block anymore. It’s matured like a fine wine (or cheese, if you’re into that). With maturity comes reliability. Developers know what to expect, and there’s a certain comfort in that familiarity.




3. Strong Community and Ecosystem
A strong community is the backbone of any successful framework. Angular’s community is vibrant, active, and ever-growing. From forums to GitHub repositories, there’s always someone ready to lend a hand or share a plugin.




4. Google’s Backing

Google LogoHaving Google as its parent is like having a superhero in your corner. Continuous updates, rigorous testing, and the assurance that it won’t be abandoned overnight make Angular a safe bet.




5. Comprehensive Tooling


Angular ToolsFrom the Angular CLI to Protractor for end-to-end testing, Angular offers a suite of tools that make development a breeze. Why reinvent the wheel when Angular provides a fully-equipped toolbox?




6. Flexibility and Scalability
Whether you’re building a simple website or a complex enterprise application, Angular scales beautifully. Its modular architecture ensures that your app remains maintainable as it grows.




7. Two-Way Data Binding


Two-Way Data Binding IllustrationThis feature, though now common in many frameworks, was a game-changer when Angular introduced it. It ensures that the model and the view are always in sync, reducing the amount of boilerplate code developers have to write.




8. A Learning Curve That’s Worth the Climb
Yes, Angular has a learning curve. But like climbing a mountain, the view from the top is worth the effort. Once mastered, developers can harness the full power of the framework, making development faster and more efficient.




9. Integration Capabilities
Angular plays well with others. Whether you’re integrating with third-party libraries or other frameworks, Angular’s flexibility shines through.




10. Future-Proofing
In the ever-evolving world of tech, Angular has shown its ability to adapt and evolve. With regular updates and a forward-thinking approach, it’s a framework that’s here to stay.




In Conclusion
Angular isn’t just surviving; it’s thriving. Its combination of maturity, robust tooling, and a strong community makes it a top choice for developers around the globe. So, the next time someone asks, “Why are developers still using Angular?”, you’ll have not one, but ten witty responses up your sleeve.
Liked this article? Don’t forget to clap and share! For more tech insights, follow me.
